sen.j: 坂上 老（さかのうえ の おきな、生年不明 - 文武天皇3年（699年）5月8日?）は、日本の飛鳥時代の人物である。
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Okina (date of birth unknown - May 8, 699?) is a person of the Asuka period of Japan.
SAKANOUE no Okina (year of birth unknown - June 13, 699?) was a person in the Asuka period of Japan.
sen.cmt: 統一リストより、date of birth unknown→year of birth unknownに修正、旧暦→新暦に修正、is→was、of the Asuka period→in the Asuka periodとしました。
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Okina (year of birth unknown - June 13, 699?) was a person in the Asuka period of Japan.

sen.j: 旧仮名遣いでの読みは「さかのうへのおきな」。
sen.e: The reading of his name is expressed as 'さかのうへのおきな' in the old kana orthography.
The reading of his name is expressed as 'さかのうへのおきな' in the old kana orthography.
The reading of his name is expressed as 'さかのうへのおきな' in the old kana orthography.

sen.j: 姓（カバネ）は直、後に忌寸。
sen.e: His kabane (the title of a chieftain of a clan in early Yamato times) was atai (直), which later changed to imiki (忌寸).
His kabane (the title of a chieftain of a clan in early Yamato times) was atai (直), which later changed to imiki (忌寸).
His kabane (the title of a chieftain of a clan in early Yamato times) was atai (直), which later changed to imiki (忌寸).

sen.j: 672年の壬申の乱で大海人皇子（天武天皇）の側につき、大伴吹負から皇子への連絡の使者になった。
sen.e: In the Jinshin War of 672, he joined the side of Oama no oji (Prince Oama, the Emperor Tenchi's younger brother, who would later become the Emperor Tenmu) and worked as OTOMO no Fukei's messenger sent to the Prince Oama.
In the Jinshin War of 672, he joined the side of Oama no oji (Prince Oama, later became the Emperor Tenmu) and worked as OTOMO no Fukei's messenger sent to the Prince Oama.
sen.cmt: the Emperor Tenchi's younger brother→原文にないため削除、who would later become→later becameとしました。
sen.e: In the Jinshin War of 672, he joined the side of Oama no oji (Prince Oama, later became the Emperor Tenmu) and worked as OTOMO no Fukei's messenger sent to the Prince Oama.

sen.j: 贈直広壱。
sen.e: He was posthumously awarded the rank of Jikikoichi (直広壱; the 10th highest in the vassals' section of the 48 court ranks instituted by the Emperor Tenmu).
He was posthumously awarded the rank of Jikikoichi (直広壱; the 10th highest in the vassals' section of the 48 court ranks instituted by the Emperor Tenmu).
He was posthumously awarded the rank of Jikikoichi (直広壱; the 10th highest in the vassals' section of the 48 court ranks instituted by the Emperor Tenmu).

sen.j: 坂上氏は渡来系の東漢氏（倭漢氏）の一族である。
sen.e: The Sakanoue clan belongs to the Yamatonoaya clan (東漢氏, also written as 倭漢氏 in Kanji), which is one of the groups of people who came from China and Korea and settled in Japan in the fourth to seventh centuries.
The Sakanoue clan belonged to the Yamatonoaya clan, which was one of the groups of people who came from China and Korea and settled in Japan in the fourth to seventh centuries.
sen.cmt: (東漢氏, also written as 倭漢氏 in Kanji)→漢字表記に関する内容のため削除、belongs→belonged、is→wasとしました。
sen.e: The Sakanoue clan belonged to the Yamatonoaya clan, which was one of the groups of people who came from China and Korea and settled in Japan in the fourth to seventh centuries.

sen.j: 東漢氏は直姓で支族が多く、大和国南部に本拠を持ち、軍事に関与することが多かった。
sen.e: The Yamatonoaya clan, being awarded a kabane of atai and based in the southern part of Yamato Province (Nara Prefecture), had many branch clans and were often engaged in the military affairs.
The Yamatonoaya clan, being awarded a kabane of atai and based in the southern part of Yamato Province (Nara Prefecture), had many branch clans and were often engaged in the military affairs.
The Yamatonoaya clan, being awarded a kabane of atai and based in the southern part of Yamato Province (Nara Prefecture), had many branch clans and were often engaged in the military affairs.

sen.j: 「坂上系図」によれば、老は坂上弓束の子で、子に坂上大国があった。
sen.e: According to 'the Genealogy of the Sakanoue Family', Okina is the son of 坂上弓束 and Okina's son is 坂上大国.
sen.cmt: ２者の名前ですが、坂上（さかのうえ）のあとが両者とも読み不明です。弓束については「ゆづか」とするサイトが一つだけありましたが、出典等不確かなので採用しておりません。
sen.e: According to 'the Genealogy of the Sakanoue Family,' Okina was the son of 坂上弓束 and Okina's son was 坂上大国.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を移動、is→wasに修正
sen.e: According to 'the Genealogy of the Sakanoue Family,' Okina was the son of 坂上弓束 and Okina's son was 坂上大国.

sen.j: 同じく壬申の乱で活躍した坂上熊毛は従兄弟である。
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Kumake, who played a lively part in the Jinshin War, was Okina's cousin.
SAKANOUE no Kumake, who played a lively part in the Jinshin War, was Okina's cousin.
SAKANOUE no Kumake, who played a lively part in the Jinshin War, was Okina's cousin.

sen.j: 壬申の年（672年）の6月に大海人皇子が挙兵すると、近江宮にいた大友皇子（弘文天皇）は倭京に使者を派遣して軍を編成させた。
sen.e: In June of the Jinshin year under the Oriental zodiac system (672), Oama no oji rose in arms against Otomo no oji (Prince Otomo, the Emperor Tenchi's son and the Emperor Kobun) who then sent a messenger to Wakyo (倭京, also read as Yamato no miyako) to organize an army.

In June of the Jinshin year under the Oriental zodiac system (672), Oama no oji rose in arms against Otomo no oji (Prince Otomo, the Emperor Kobun) who then sent a messenger to Wakyo (倭京, also read as Yamato no miyako) to organize an army.
sen.cmt: the Emperor Tenchi's son→原文にないため削除
sen.e: In June of the Jinshin year under the Oriental zodiac system (672), Oama no oji rose in arms against Otomo no oji (Prince Otomo, the Emperor Kobun) who then sent a messenger to Wakyo (倭京, also read as Yamato no miyako) to organize an army.

sen.j: 倭はここでは大和のことで、倭京は飛鳥におかれた古い都のことである。
sen.e: Here, Wa (倭) means Yamato (大和) and Wakyo means an old capital established in the place of Asuka (飛鳥; in Nara Prefecture).
Here, Wa (倭) means Yamato (大和) and Wakyo means an old capital established in the place of Asuka (飛鳥; in Nara Prefecture).
Here, Wa (倭) means Yamato (大和) and Wakyo means an old capital established in the place of Asuka (飛鳥; in Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: しかしこのとき、大海人皇子側につくことを決めた大伴吹負は挙兵をめざして人数を集め、倭京の留守司の一人坂上熊毛とともに、一二の漢直に内応を求めた。
sen.e: At this time, however, OTOMO no Fukei, having made up his mind to work for Oama no oji, started to collect soldiers to raise an army and established secret communication with SAKANOUE no Kumake who was one of Wakyo's rusutsukasa (guards of the city) then and with twelve clans of ayanoatai (漢直) at the same time.

At this time, however, OTOMO no Fukei, having made up his mind to work for Oama no oji, started to collect soldiers to raise an army and established secret communication with SAKANOUE no Kumake who was one of the Wakyo's rusutsukasa (guards of the city) then and with twelve clans of ayanoatai (漢直) at the same time.
sen.cmt: one of Wakyo's→one of the Wakyo'sとし、余分なスペース消去
sen.e: At this time, however, OTOMO no Fukei, having made up his mind to work for Oama no oji, started to collect soldiers to raise an army and established secret communication with SAKANOUE no Kumake who was one of the Wakyo's rusutsukasa (guards of the city) then and with twelve clans of ayanoatai (漢直) at the same time.

sen.j: 漢直とは倭漢氏を指す。
sen.e: Ayanoatai means people of the Yamato no aya clan (倭漢氏).
Ayanoatai means people of the Yamatonoaya clan.
sen.cmt: 前出の表記にあわせ、Yamato no aya clan→Yamatonoaya clanとし、漢字表記削除
sen.e: Ayanoatai means people of the Yamatonoaya clan.

sen.j: 6月29日、まず秦熊が使者のふりをして馬に乗って馳せ、「高市皇子が不破から来た」と誤報を言った。
sen.e: On June 29, a person called HADA no Kuma rode a horse, being disguised as a messenger, to the camp of Otomo no oji and spread a false news saying, "Takechi no miko (Prince Takechi, the son of Oama no oji) arrived from Fuwa (Prince Takechi's base in Mino Province, the southern part of Gifu Prefecture)."
sen.cmt: 「秦熊」という人名については（ルール違反かも知れませんが）同名のＷｉｋｉｐｅｄｉａの内容を参考にしました。誤報の内容が２文であるため別々のセルに配置されています。よって”と誤報を言った。”という部分を第１文に付けました。
sen.e: On June 29, a person called HADA no Kuma rode a horse, being disguised as a messenger, to the camp of Otomo no oji and spread a false news saying, 'Takechi no miko (Prince Takechi) arrived from Fuwa (Prince Takechi's base in Mino Province, the southern part of Gifu Prefecture).'
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、the son of Oama no oji→原文にないため削除
sen.e: On June 29, a person called HADA no Kuma rode a horse, being disguised as a messenger, to the camp of Otomo no oji and spread a false news saying, 'Takechi no miko (Prince Takechi) arrived from Fuwa (Prince Takechi's base in Mino Province, the southern part of Gifu Prefecture).'

sen.j: また「軍衆が多く従っている」とも。
sen.e: "He is accompanied with a great many soldiers," added Hada no Kuma.
sen.cmt: 上のセルからの続きで、誤報の第2文を左のように修正しました。
sen.e: He is accompanied with a great many soldiers,' added Hada no Kuma.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: He is accompanied with a great many soldiers,' added Hada no Kuma.

sen.j: 陣営の兵士は驚いて逃げ散った。
sen.e: Being so freightened by the false news, the soldiers of Otomo no oji army quickly fled away.
Being so freightened by the false news, the soldiers of Otomo no oji army quickly fled away.
Being so freightened by the false news, the soldiers of Otomo no oji army quickly fled away.

sen.j: それから数十騎で乗り込むと、熊毛と諸々の直が内応したため、吹負は難なく指揮権を奪取した。
sen.e: Then OTOMO no Fukei rode into Wakyo with several dozens of mounted warriers and easily captured the right of command over the place, owing also to the betrayal of Kumake and various atai (直) clan people.

Then OTOMO no Fukei rode into Wakyo with several dozens of mounted warriers and easily captured the right of command over the place, owing also to the betrayal of Kumake and various atai (直) clan people.

Then OTOMO no Fukei rode into Wakyo with several dozens of mounted warriers and easily captured the right of command over the place, owing also to the betrayal of Kumake and various atai (直) clan people.

sen.j: 坂上老も熊毛と同族で「直」の一人であるから、ここで内応した一人である可能性が高い。
sen.e: As SAKANOUE no Okina was one of the same 'atai' clans as Kumake, it is highly likely that he was one of those who colluded with Kumake then and there.
As SAKANOUE no Okina was one of the same 'atai' clans as Kumake, it is highly likely that he was one of those who colluded with Kumake then and there.
As SAKANOUE no Okina was one of the same 'atai' clans as Kumake, it is highly likely that he was one of those who colluded with Kumake then and there.

sen.j: ことが成功してから、大友吹負は不破宮にいた大海人皇子に報告の使者を派遣した。
sen.e: On attaining victory, OTOMO no Fukei sent messengers to Oama no oji who was then in the Fuwanomiya Palace to report on the success.
On attaining victory, OTOMO no Fukei sent messengers to Oama no oji who was then in the Fuwanomiya Palace to report on the success.
On attaining victory, OTOMO no Fukei sent messengers to Oama no oji who was then in the Fuwanomiya Palace to report on the success.

sen.j: 大伴安麻呂、坂上老、佐味宿那麻呂がその使者になった。
sen.e: The messengers were OTOMO no Yasumaro, SAKANOUE no Okina and SAMI no Sukunamaro.
The messengers were OTOMO no Yasumaro, SAKANOUE no Okina and SAMI no Sukunamaro.
The messengers were OTOMO no Yasumaro, SAKANOUE no Okina and SAMI no Sukunamaro.

sen.j: 彼等は無事に役目を果たしたが、そのあとの戦争での坂上老の行動については記録がない。
sen.e: They performed their duties successfully, but no records have been found on the actions of SAKANOUE no Okina in the subsequent wars.
They performed their duties successfully, but no records have been found on the actions of SAKANOUE no Okina in the subsequent wars.
They performed their duties successfully, but no records have been found on the actions of SAKANOUE no Okina in the subsequent wars.

sen.j: 佐味宿名麻呂は戻って倭の方面で戦ったから、老もそうしたかもしれないが、別の方面にいた可能性もある。
sen.e: SAMI no Sukunamaro is known to have returned to Yamato area (Nara Prefecture) to continue to fight, and so SAKANOUE no Okina may have done the same, but there is a chance that he went to some other place.

SAMI no Sukunamaro is known to have returned to Yamato area (Nara Prefecture) to continue to fight, and so SAKANOUE no Okina may have done the same, but there is a chance that he went to some other place.

SAMI no Sukunamaro is known to have returned to Yamato area (Nara Prefecture) to continue to fight, and so SAKANOUE no Okina may have done the same, but there is a chance that he went to some other place.

sen.j: 倭漢直は、天武天皇11年（682年）5月12日に、連の姓を与えられた。
sen.e: Yamato no ayanoatai people were awarded a kabane of muraji (連) on May 12, 682.
Yamato no ayanoatai people were awarded a kabane of muraji (連) on June 25, 682.
Yamato no ayanoatai people were awarded a kabane of muraji (連) on June 25, 682.

sen.j: 倭漢連は、天武天皇14年（685年）6月20日に、忌寸の姓を与えられた。
sen.e: Yamato no ayanoatai people were awarded a kabane of imiki on June 20, 685.
Yamato no ayanoatai people were awarded a kabane of imiki on July 29, 685.
Yamato no ayanoatai people were awarded a kabane of imiki on July 29, 685.

sen.j: 坂上氏もこの中にあって直から連へ、また忌寸へと変わったと推定できる。
sen.e: It is possible to presume that the SAKANOUE clan was among such people, and that their kabane has changed from atai to muraji, and then to imiki.
It is possible to presume that the SAKANOUE clan was among such people, and that their kabane had changed from atai to muraji, and then to imiki.
It is possible to presume that the SAKANOUE clan was among such people, and that their kabane had changed from atai to muraji, and then to imiki.

sen.j: 文武天皇3年（699年）5月8日に天皇は次のような詔を発した。
sen.e: On May 8, 699, the Emperor Monmu issued an Imperial edict as below.
On June 13, 699, the Emperor Monmu issued an Imperial edict as below.
On June 13, 699, the Emperor Monmu issued an Imperial edict as below.

sen.j: 「図勲の義は前を修めることから始まり、創功の賞は歴代これを重んじる。
sen.e: The honorable deed begins with managing whatever comes from of you and the importance of recognizing the great achievements shall be stressed through the coming generations.
The honorable deed begins with managing whatever comes from of you and the importance of recognizing the great achievements shall be stressed through the coming generations.
The honorable deed begins with managing whatever comes from of you and the importance of recognizing the great achievements shall be stressed through the coming generations.

sen.j: 壮士の節をあきらかにし、不朽の名をあらわすためである。
sen.e: This is to define the brave men and perpetuate the names of such persons.
This is to define the brave men and perpetuate the names of such persons.
This is to define the brave men and perpetuate the names of such persons.

sen.j: 汝、坂上忌寸老は壬申の年の軍役に自分の命をかえりみず、社稷の急に赴き、万死を出て国難に立ち向かった。
sen.e: When engaged in the military service in the year of Jinshin, you, SAKANOUE no Imiki Okina, took yourself off to face the national crisis and confronted it regardless of the risk of losing your life and narrowly escaping certain death.

When engaged in the military service in the year of Jinshin, you, SAKANOUE no Imiki Okina, took yourself off to face the national crisis and confronted it regardless of the risk of losing your life and narrowly escaping certain death.

When engaged in the military service in the year of Jinshin, you, SAKANOUE no Imiki Okina, took yourself off to face the national crisis and confronted it regardless of the risk of losing your life and narrowly escaping certain death.

sen.j: そしてまだはっきり功賞されずに急死した。
sen.e: And you suddenly died without being properly rewarded.
And you suddenly died without being properly rewarded.
And you suddenly died without being properly rewarded.

sen.j: 死後に優遇して冥途で慰めようと思う。
sen.e: I would like to grant you a favorable treatment, even posthumously, and comfort you in the kingdom of the dead.
I would like to grant you a favorable treatment, even posthumously, and comfort you in the kingdom of the dead.
I would like to grant you a favorable treatment, even posthumously, and comfort you in the kingdom of the dead.

sen.j: 直広壱を贈り、物を与えよ」と。
sen.e: Now, grant him the rank of Jikikoichi and award him prizes.
sen.cmt: ”」と。”の部分は次のセルに独立して入っていたものを左のセルに統合しました。
sen.e: Now, grant him the rank of Jikikoichi and award him prizes.
Now, grant him the rank of Jikikoichi and award him prizes.

sen.j: 坂上老はこの日か少し前に死んだと推測できる。
sen.e: Presumably SAKANOUE no Okina died on or shortly before this day.
Presumably SAKANOUE no Okina died on or shortly before this day.
Presumably SAKANOUE no Okina died on or shortly before this day.

sen.j: 壬申の功臣の死に際しての恩典を記す箇所は、『日本書紀』と『続日本紀』に数多いが、老に対するものがもっとも詳しい。
sen.e: In the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and the "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Copntinued), there are many references to the special privileges granted posthmously to the meritorious retainers in relation to the Jinshin War, and the most detailed of all is the one to the Okina's case.

In the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and the "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Copntinued), there are many references to the special privileges granted posthmously to the meritorious retainers in relation to the Jinshin War, and the most detailed of all is the one to the Okina's case.

In the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and the "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Copntinued), there are many references to the special privileges granted posthmously to the meritorious retainers in relation to the Jinshin War, and the most detailed of all is the one to the Okina's case.

sen.j: しかしこれは、老に対する評価が最高ということではないらしい。
sen.e: However, this apparently does not necessarily mean that Okina was evaluated higher than anybody else.
However, this apparently does not necessarily mean that Okina was evaluated higher than anybody else.
However, this apparently does not necessarily mean that Okina was evaluated higher than anybody else.
